question: Find the spring constant of the bimetallic bar shown in <image 1> in axial motion.
description:
The image depicts a composite bimetallic bar consisting of two materials: steel and aluminum. The bar has a rectangular cross-section with dimensions specified as follows:

- The total width (along the x-axis) of the bar is 2 cm.
- The height (along the y-axis) of the bar is 0.5 cm.
- The length of the bar (along the z-axis, perpendicular to the plane of the image) is 0.5 m.

The bar is divided into two sections along its height:
- The top section is made of steel, occupying the upper half of the height (0.25 cm).
- The bottom section is made of aluminum, occupying the lower half of the height (0.25 cm).

The Young's modulus (E) for each material is provided:
- For steel: \( E_{\text{steel}} = 207 \times 10^9 \) Pa.
- For aluminum: \( E_{\text{aluminum}} = 83 \times 10^9 \) Pa.

The problem involves finding the equivalent spring constant (\( k_{\text{eq}} \)) of this bimetallic bar in axial motion. The options given for \( k_{\text{eq}} \) are:
A. \( k_{\text{eq}} = 4.80 \times 10^7 \frac{N}{m} \)
B. \( k_{\text{eq}} = 5.80 \times 10^7 \frac{N}{m} \)
C. \( k_{\text{eq}} = 6.80 \times 10^7 \frac{N}{m} \)

To solve this, one would need to calculate the individual stiffnesses of the steel and aluminum sections and then combine them appropriately to find the equivalent stiffness of the entire bar.
